rev.comment: /* Criticism and 'cult' allegations */ +ref-- ODAN ref, but _only_ to point out that critics mention this. 1 sec for ref about factuality
/* Controversy */ alright-- if we're give a prose version a shot, we can't just collapse the bullet points, have to make it less dense
/* Contemporary responses to Opus Dei */ bullets to prose, a first step
fix broken cite-- everyone be extra careful not to delete named cites-- you can end up deleteing 5 cites at once. copy named cite to second instance
/* Corporal Mortification */ between the 12, I'd say that should settle that :)
/* Corporal Mortification */ ok, here are 10 more cites showing that cilices are worn daily for more than one hour. I'm leaving them in comments to avoid ref bombing-- promote as many as you want
/* Corporal Mortification */ reinstate deleted refs-- do not delete refs,especially named ones, you break the page. Add fact tag. Also added link to reliable mirror at Internet Archive
/* Corporal Mortification */ fix ref, slight structural change, add "see below" link to criticism section
/* Corporal Mortification */ rickross is a blog, not a valid source ODAN is also a blog-like publication and not a primary source rplaced with fact tags as is practice here
please-- don't delete sources. If you want more reliable ones, add the fact tag so I can try to find even better ones.
/* Corporal Mortification */ more-controversial is a badly hyphenated term need UNBAISed and trustworthy references
/* Corporal Mortification */ hmm. agree that "more-discussed" wasn't quite right, but let's not drag DaVinci into it. lol.
/* Other Wikipedia articles on Opus Dei */ even columns
-no need to mention mortification in "types of membership"
/* Criticism and 'cult' allegations */ -"cult watch groups" as critics. It's factually and verifiably true, but I can live with not hitting readers over the head with it.
-listing Jesuits as current critics. It's factually true to some extent, but I get the idea that's more of a historical criticism than a current one, and we mention it above
/* Criticism and 'cult' allegations */ mv ref to within sentence
nothing dubious about cilice image-- all sources agree this is what cilices look like. See Allen book for example, History Channel special also shows identical one
partial self revert, for history clarity
but we can comment out the two of the three Hitler refs. The International Herald Tribune should suffice
these two refs talk about hitler
Most critics are not ODAN members (opus libros, del Carmen Tapia, Hutchison, Estruch, Walsh, others). will add cites to clarify
"the Kingdom of God" -> "the kingdom of God". Wasn't capitalized in original, thogh perhaps it should have been. Think it has something to do with the "the" in front
"penitential mortification" -> "corporal mortification" or simply "mortification". OD doesn't use that term, their term is corporal mortification. Not done as part of penance for specific acts
/* Criticism and 'cult' allegations */ bullet point to prose, express which claims come from ODAN and which come from others (including proper use of ref's)
/* Doctrine */ Copyedit. Joining up paragraphs. The Escrivà quote isn't actually famous outside the organization; avoid writing "from the inside."
/* Contemporary responses to Opus Dei */ proper use of sources - the material in the sources did not match the material that was claiming to be ref'd by them; fixed
/* History of Opus Dei */ rm "Opus Dei founder"--the man has already been named as the founder of Opus Dei *ten times* in this short section, I think we've got it.

/* History of Opus Dei */ Reorganize, and rm 1) poor placing of "Catholic entity", 2) unreasonable imputation of an *attitude* (anti-clericalism) to a *war* (the Spanish Civil War), and 3) some typos.
/* Penitential Mortification */ the image is not dubious
/* Mortification in Opus Dei */ title, specific
/* Mortification in Opus Dei */ pic is of doubious origin, hiding until some verification can be provided

/* Criticism and 'cult' allegations */ do not ref bomb, its unencyclopedic - I placed the refs in their proper place (only one mentioned HItler) and removed 2 that did not mention him, Franco, or Pino
/* Mortification in Opus Dei */ move paragraph for structure
/* Types of membership */ cleanup, we don't need to say unmarried members are celibate, or that married members lead "trad. family lives" (its obvious); only state who does mortify, nor who does not
/* Structure and activities */ cleanup, wordiness and so on
/* History of Opus Dei */ remove wordiness
move summary of group ahead of summary of history, remove redundant statement, also we need not mention in intro the women were not admitted until 2 years after inception - trivial
/* Historical responses to Opus Dei */ it's => its
intro-- I think I personally like Bish's wording on these parts better. "Escriva allowed women" seems a tad harsh, for example.
Trying to organize the intro more coherently and more NPOV, please see Talk.
/* Opus Dei in popular culture */"claims" instead of "says", it's unlikely he ever spoke with actual members
/* Mortification in Opus Dei */ adding Indy cite for "blood on the bathroom walls"
rv Escriva's mortification. Let's not say too much about this, and when we do, let's keep the focus on OD itself. Extensive discussion on Escriva's practice should go on his article
/* Mortification in Opus Dei */ who himself practiced self-mortification with great vigor. -- needs a cite, I'll take a look
/* Mortification in Opus Dei */ The practice of self-mortification in Opus Dei mirrors that of Josemaría Escrivá, who himself practiced self-mortification.
/* Support and rebuttals */ hehe be sure to link to a version that actually says "take up the cross"
/* Support and rebuttals */ format with full citation
replaced with better cite (and moved named cite to second instance)
reinstate deleted cites for now, but adding "citation wanted" tags and will now look for better cites
/* History of Opus Dei */ rm tag from site that seemed like a blog, I guess it passes muster since it is directly related to topic
reference is not a primary source
subst Dubious templae for a fix
heres one cite that refers to it as "the work" a lot. If anyone knows of one that explicitly says "OD is sometimes called just The Work", do substitute-- i'll keep looking
restore that cite since it provides the latin translation, but i'll look for a cite for referring to it was "the work", add fact tag for now
Rm cite--I can't find anything about OD being called "The Work" at this link. Sorry if I'm simply missing it. But also, known to whom? Please indicate if it's a pet name used by members/supporters.
